text: A lot of the procedures that I've been giving you in the guided meditation, guided meditations so far in the retreat, I really need to explain to you are not exactly meditation techniques. They are what I call sensitizing exercises. And I apologize if it has seemed extremely elaborate and confusing. Basically, I've mostly given you exercises to explore the interconnection between the fundamental components of subjective and even to a certain extent relationships between the subjective components and the objective world. I made a list of how many different circuits that I'm aware of that can be teased out in terms of relationships within the subjective triad of talk, image and feel, and then between the objective world of sight, sound and touch, and the subjective world of talk, image and feel. And I got about two dozen. But that doesn't mean there are two dozen meditation techniques that you're going to have to master. These, as I say, are just exercises that I give people to sensitize them, to sort of become aware of relationships, so that when you do one of the standard techniques, of which there's only a few, all those strands and connections will have been teased out, and you'll be able to free-float among talk, image and feel, or evenly cover, or systematic inventories. For working with the self, it basically boils down to just those three techniques. I've also given some of you a way of focusing on the breath, which is designed to be primarily a concentration exercise, but also, while it's building concentration, to sensitize you once again to the fundamental elements. And one can alternate, as I mentioned the first day of the retreat, there's a complementary interplay between techniques that focus away from the self, and techniques that focus on the self. And among the techniques that focus away from the self, many of them are rather narrow focuses that develop high concentration. And then you can use that concentration like a laser when you focus on the self, to get the penetration and the insight. And you can alternate back and forth between the narrower focus and the broader focus. However, it's important to realize that even when you do a very narrow focus, let's say that you were to decide that you wanted to keep things real simple, just going to focus on the physical sensation of the breath in your abdomen, or at your nostril, and that's what your path is going to be. Five years, ten years, fifteen years, twenty years, thirty years, just keep it simple, that's what you're going to do. That's enough, that'll do it. At first it will be a concentration exercise. Your mind will wander, you bring it back, it wanders, you bring it back. But if you do it long enough, even those very limited simple focuses bring elements of insight and purification. How does that happen? Well, if you focus on one aspect of experience, even if your interest is in developing concentration, you have to be doing some observation of what's going on, you have to be paying attention to what's going on with the breath. And the more closely you pay attention, the more you can start to see how it's constantly changing. And then, also in order to stay in the moment with it, you have to be willing to let go, moment by moment, instant by instant, of the previous sensation there, in order to be present for the next arising of sensation. And the sensation begins to melt and yield and dissolve. Now you're getting insight into impermanence. Yes, it's impermanence of one little piece of experience, but it's still impermanence. And at some point, your perception of impermanence associated with the sensations of the breath becomes so great that that impermanence reaches out and starts to grab the whole body and all the senses, and you get pulled into a profound insight, into the insubstantial, oscillatory, and vibratory nature of all the sense gates, even though you had a very narrow focus. So, insight can develop from what is primarily a concentration exercise. Purification is also there too, although you might not realize it. Because in order to focus on, let's say, the sensation of the breath, you're having to let go of a lot of ego patterns. You can't focus on the sensation of the breath, and at the same time being involved in talk, image, and feel, because you're with the touch of the breath. And if you're really just with the touch of the breath, you'll start to notice that each time you feel this temptation to somehow get involved in the content of talk, image, and feel, and you resist that temptation, well, you've let go of a little bit of ego grasping there. You've weakened a little bit of the ego habits. In fact, one of the reasons that it's so difficult to focus on a small piece of experience that's neutral, like the breath, why it feels like you're just going to die, is you are. A little piece of the ego is going to die. And it's the time when you would give anything to indulge some aspect of yourself, it's at the time when instead of doing that, you stay with the breath, even though it is literally mortifyingly boring. It's at that time, whether you realize it or not, that purification is taking place. There is a cracking of the ego taking place. And when it's mortifying, it is mortifying. It's a petit mort, a little piece of ego death is taking place at that time. You might not realize it, as I say, your primary goal might just be to get a little calm and concentration. But it's doing what the Yaqui shaman, Don Juan, called shifting the accumulation point of the universe. When you just can't stand to focus on that small boring thing anymore and you still do it, something shifts and the whole universe is a cracking of a piece of the ego. So even a narrow focus, if you understand it properly, brings insight and purification. But it's helpful to understand it properly. Personally though, I use a little different strategy for the insight and purification, which I would never for a moment claim is any better. It's just, I like it. I like to alternate working with individual pieces of experience, selectively, and then putting those pieces together and working collectively, and then working once again selectively, and then working once again collectively. So you sort of understand the components and then you understand the relationship with the components. Why? Because I get bored focusing on something small. So I find it more interesting to focus on a lot of small things and then focus on the big picture, and it just keeps me interested in the meditation process. And so that's sort of the rationale behind some of the exercises that I've been giving you. One of the exercises that I had you do was pay attention to the sounds around you and monitor whether a sound produced a feeling reaction in the body or not, and then monitor whether a sound produced an image reaction in the body or not, and then monitor the effect of the sound on your internal talking, whether it triggered talk by way of comment about the sound or whether it turned off talk. Because self-talk is a kind of internal hearing, a lot of times external sound will actually turn it off for a minute, make it silent. But sometimes it will stimulate it. If you hear a sound that, you know, let me put it this way, if you hear a sound and that sound causes a feeling, very likely there'll be some talk. So what I was having you do is tease out certain circuits, the circuit that links sound to talk, the circuit that links external sound to image, the circuit that links external sound to a body reaction, a feel. Then what I had you do is listen to sound and be aware of what combination of talk, image, and feel would arise moment by moment in reaction to the sound. There being exactly eight possibilities. One of the possibilities being no reaction. Another possibility being talk, image, and feel arise. And then you could have just talk, just image, just feel, or any one of three possible pairs. The purpose of the exercise, actually quite profound, because you're exploring how the sense of a perceiving self, a listening self arises. How the sense of a listening self arises. If you do this for some period of time, and I'm not suggesting you do it, I'm just saying if one did this, you would start to gather data. It's very much like a scientific experiment. You're not going to get a paradigm shift, any big ah-ha's or answers, doing it just a few times. But as you gather a lot of data, perhaps over a period of weeks, months, maybe years, you'll start to notice some things. Insights will start to arise. Shifts in understanding. You'll notice that just spontaneously, every once in a while, there really is just sound without any reaction. It just happens. Not because of this or that, it's just the probabilities of things. And as you become sensitive to what that's like, you'll notice it's quite interesting. Because when there's just sound, the sound fills your space and you surround its space, and you are the sound. There is just the it and no perceiver. And that's an extremely... that expands your boundaries of identity. Personally, I think an effective strategy for learning how to do this is not really to try to do it, but just pay attention to whatever reactions take place and wait for the law of averages to catch up. And you'll start to get enough times when there's just sound, and then it starts to be clear what that is, and then you can do it as an act of will. You can decide to just be sound for a while. Technically, to borrow terminology from another tradition, from the tradition of yoga, Raja Yoga, Ashtanga Yoga, Patanjali's Yoga, the classical yoga of India, you do understand that the physical yoga is Hatha Yoga. That's quite something else. In India, in terms of philosophy, when you say yoga, it implies one of the six basic principles or one of the six classic systems of Indian philosophy, what are called the Shat Darshana, the six Darshanas, the six views. There is the yoga system, as formulated by Patanjali in the Yoga Sutras, the Yoga aphorisms. And there they speak of Sabija Samadhi. It means samadhi in the sense of merging, not merely in the sense of concentration, but in the sense of merging, becoming. Sabija with a C, that means that there's no perceiver, but there is the perceived. And that sounds very mysterious until you start to investigate your talk, image, and feel reactions to sound. And then it's not mysterious at all. You come to realize that every once in a while, there's just sound. You don't have to make it happen, it just happens. It's probabilities. And when that happens, you are the sound. There's just the seed, there's just the object, there's just the sound without a you being there, listening. Well, you say, well, who hears? No one. There's just the manifestation of sound. The sense of someone hearing always involves some subtle level of talk, image, and feel reaction. And as you start to see that, you start to get another insight. You get the insight as to how the sense of a listening self arises. And when there is a reaction of talk, image, and feel, there's the sense of I'm over here listening to it over there, and there's separation. Is that bad? No, that's not bad. It's not bad at all. Is it better to just be sound and have no separation? Is that better than the sense of a self arising listening to sound? No, it's not better. One is not better than the other. What's good and bad is as follows. What's bad is to not know how the sense of self arises and how the sense of oneness arises. That's bad. And what's good is to know that. Then you're free. You're free to live in a world of oneness. You're free to live in a world of separateness. And you're free from a preference between them. Because when the self arises separate from the sound, as long as that self is clear and fluent, that is to say, you understand why it has arisen. Because there's talk, image, and feel happening in reaction to the sound. And that's natural. That's as much a part of nature as the cricket's chirping is part of nature. That a self should arise in a human being is part of nature. But for most people, it arises incompletely, in the sense that they're not aware of the components, number one, and there is subtle and not so subtle interference between the components and congealing and friction and fixation. The talk, image, and feel don't just flow like a river. They don't just spread like ripples or blow like the wind. They're not spirit. They get frozen, interfered with. When we say in English, I became self-conscious, it implies an uncomfortable experience. That's very strange if you think about it. Why should it be uncomfortable to be intensely self-conscious? Suffering equals pain multiplied by resistance. We must resist the arising of our sense of self. We must be interfering, pushing and pulling on it, and therefore it becomes an uncomfortable experience. So you start to see clearly how the sense of I versus it arises. You also see what happens when there's not an I versus it, but there's just it, and I am it. And that happens with respect to sound, and it's exactly the same with respect to vision. In Zen, these are the first koans that are given. How do you become free when you hear this sound? That's the classic Sasaki Roshi initial koan. Or how do you become free when you see the pine tree or see the flower? What's being asked for? Well, actually, many levels of experience are being asked for. One level of experience is you've listened and listened and listened and listened enough until you start to have that experience of I am the sound. But I find it, as I say, a little easier if you actually just monitor the sound and the reactions to the sound, and then that will give you the insights. And that will also give you the insight of, the beginning of the insight of how the sense of an individual self arises. So, okay, that's sound. What about the visual field? Well, you look here, you look here, you look here. Each one of those is a new arising of vision. But what happens when you look at just one thing, like a pine tree? You're looking just at the pine tree. Well, your eye goes here, it goes there, it goes there, it goes there. Your eye traces out the activity of the pine tree, the structure of the branches and leaves. And each time it shifts, there is an arising of a piece of the visual field that constitutes that pine tree. If there is just the activity of seeing the pine tree, without any talk, image or feel arising in reaction to each little permutation of the visual axis, then after 10, 20 seconds of that, one begins to have the experience of the pine tree fills me, I embrace the pine tree, I am the pine tree, there is no me. Of course, substitute pine tree for your lover or your enemy, and now you're starting to talk about enlightenment, about really understanding the oneness of things. Touches on the body, same thing, external physical touches. How do you become free from hot and cold? External physical touches, a famous Zen koan, most of you have heard the answer to it. I use it at retreats, the monk comes to the Master, how do you become free from hot and cold? The Master says, well, why not go to a place where there is no hot or cold? And the monk says, tell me about that place. And the Master says, when it's hot, you boil to death. When it's cold, you freeze to death. You understand? Boil to death, you're too busy boiling to have talk, image or feel. You're just heat. You're too busy freezing to have any reaction, you just have the touch. No talk, image or feel. You become hot, you become cold, that's the place where you're free from hot and cold. Why? Well, as Ananda Maitreya, the grand old man of Sri Lankan Buddhism, put it, when he was interviewed for the BBC and asked to express in a few words the essence of Buddhism, he said, I need only four. No self, no problem. I had the privilege of living with this man in the same Vihara Sri Lankan temple, Sri Lanka. I was in LA, but I might as well have been in Sri Lanka. It's pretty cool. So, touch, sight, sound. And what about all of them at once? Okay, same thing. How do you become free when you listen to the pine tree, hug it and see it all at once? Okay, same thing. The external sense is them only. Sabija Samadhi. There is the shining forth of the object without the sense of self perceiving it. As I say, you can learn it by trying to do it, or you can learn it by just watching the nature of your reaction to the external sense impacts without any particular preference, until you start to see the statistical distribution of reactions and you notice it, as I say, every once in a while, it just happens. It happens because there's eight possible reactions, and one of those eight is no talk, no image, no feel. And if you're watching, watching, watching, over and over and over and over and over again, you start to notice these things. One insight is an insight into oneness, how you can be the external world. It's wonderful, it's empowering, it frees you from fear. Wherever there's fear, there's separateness. Wherever there's separateness, there's fear. A implies B, B implies A. That means A and B are exactly the same thing. So, you can come to oneness by working through fear. How do you work through fear? By having a complete experience of fear. Or you can work through fear by experiencing oneness. How do you experience oneness? I just described it. If it didn't quite register, that's okay, I'll describe it again and again and again. I won't get tired of describing it, I promise you that. So one insight is insight into oneness. But another insight is insight into how separation arises, and that's important too. It's deep, very deep. I can, yes, I can describe it with a metaphor. The metaphor is very good. It's almost a perfect metaphor. It just has one flaw. It's not dignified. And for such a profound and important subject as how the sense of self arises, I wish I could find a more dignified metaphor, or at least a more classy or classical sounding metaphor. But I haven't been able to. But at least I found what I consider to be a pretty good one. Many of you have heard it. I come into your room, you've got your computer on, and on the screen there's white, maybe in addition to other colors, whatever, there are white graphics, a white figure of some sort, and I tell you, there's no white there. And you say, come on, you can see it. And I say, no, there's no white there. You want me to prove it? I'll give you something that magnifies exactly what is there, changes nothing. Take this magnifying glass, get close to the screen, look at the white and tell me exactly what you see when you look with the magnifying glass close up. And what will you see? White? What will you see? Yes, RGB, red, green, and blue pixel dots. That's what's actually there. When you look close up with the magnifying glass, and when you don't look close up with the magnifying glass, white is there. So what is the reality of white? What is the reality of something that appears as soon as you lose contact with exactly what's there, and disappears as soon as you establish contact with exactly what's there? To what extent is that thing there? It's a very interesting question. In a sense it's there, I mean, look, it's white. It's there, but not really. So it sort of exists and doesn't exist. I think you can see my metaphor. Is there a thing called a self inside us? Well, we all have a sense of self, certainly. But is there really a limited existence, a thing called a self inside us, an atma? It sort of seems that way. Remember, the Buddha didn't say there wasn't a self. The Buddha didn't say there wasn't a soul. The Buddha said there is no atma, or no atta. He was speaking Sanskrit or a mid-Indian dialect, or Pali, or something like Pali. He was not speaking English. Self is an English word, soul is an English word. He said there's no atma. Atma is more or less means self, but not exactly. It has a different context, it's a different language. The semantic extent and the connotation of the word in Sanskrit and Pali and other Indic languages is not exactly the same as English. So, what implies self as thing? It's a very reified sense of self, a self-particle. Buddha was reacting to that perception of self. And we have that perception, undeniably. We have the perception that there's a thing inside us called a self. But is there? Well, it's quite analogous to the white on the computer screen. If you don't look carefully, it's there. But if you take the magnifying glass of mindfulness and investigate what's actually there, what's actually there is talk, image, and feel, either in its clear form or its subtle subliminal forms. That's what's actually there. And the interesting thing is, as soon as you take the magnifying glass of mindfulness to the perception of I am a thing, the I am-ness goes away, just like the white does, and you're left with talk, image, and feel. So, how does the sense of self arise? It arises when talk, image, and feel arise, and you lose contact with them. And when talk, image, and feel arise and you have a complete experience of them, you're able to not lose contact with them, then the sense of self, this thing, does not arise. Then what does arise? Moksha, a sense of freedom, as opposed to a sense of limited identity. So that's why it's perfectly okay that there be a reaction of talk, image, and feel to sight, sound, and touch, as long as you're able to keep track of it and don't interfere with it. Then you'll have a kind of self, but it's a clear and fluent self. Therefore we call it a transparent and insubstantial self, or self as activity, as opposed to self as thing. So that's a big insight. So by tracking, like I say, I know that some of the exercises I gave you are pretty frustrating. There is a reason behind it. By tracking these kinds of relationships, we can get insights fairly readily. How can we become one with our world? And how does the sense of separateness arise specifically? What's involved? What are the steps? What are the components? What are the relationships? So in one experience of samadhi, there is just sight, sound, touch as an object, and no talk, image, and feel at all. In another aspect of samadhi, talk, image, and feel may arise by way of reaction, but it's so clear and fluent that it is diaphanous, it is transparent. So once again, there is just sight, sound, and touch. I am the world. But there is a deeper samadhi than that. There is nirbija samadhi, samadhi without a seed. What does that mean? Well, I've talked about sight, sound, and touch arising as an object, but if you have a complete experience of sight, sound, or touch, you're too busy experiencing it to congeal it into a thing. So then what happens is, not only does the sense of self arise as a flow of nothingness, but the thing that you're concentrating on, the sound, arises as a flow of nothingness. And there is what is called formless samadhi. You're merged, but you're so completely merged that there's no knowing. That's why it's called asamprajñāta samadhi. It's another term for it. I'm using yogic terms here, but it's the same as Buddhism, let's be honest. When the Zen Master was talking about going to a place where there is no hot and cold, it wasn't just that there is no self experiencing hot and cold, but it also implied that the experience of hot and cold was so complete that hot and cold as an object disappeared. Now that may seem rather bleak, but actually it's very rich, because the self and the object don't disappear into bleakness, they disappear into completeness. The experience is so rich that it doesn't exist anymore. Not that it's so deprived that it doesn't exist anymore. So because the path to the emptiness is by having more and more and more complete experiences, the emptiness is perceived as extremely rich, in fact as the ultimately rich. I know it's a paradox, it doesn't really make a lot of sense when you try to put it into words, but all the mystics all around the world in all the ages agree on this, and a lot of them never communicated with each other, they just discovered it independently. Sort of like the Pythagorean theorem. The Greeks discovered it on their own, the Chinese discovered it on their own, people in India discovered it on their own, but it's the same theorem, because it's intrinsic in the nature of mathematical reality. Well, just like the Pythagorean theorem is a universal reality, this rich bleakness of the source is independently discovered in the different traditions, which gives us a strong indication that there's something there. It's not something true, because it's not limited to one tradition. I said that the TV metaphor was a pretty good one, because not only does it give an analog to how a property emerges, it's what's called an emergent property in consciousness science. The white is an emergent property. It magically emerges from red, green, and blue. It's not red, it's not green, it's not blue, and it's not a compromise. It's not a mixture of red, green, and blue. It's a completely different critter. The sense of I am a limited identity, I am a thing, it's not talk, it's not image, it's not feel, and it's not some compromise between those. It's a completely different thing that somehow emerges from those when you lose track of them. And it fails to emerge when you stay with just what is. The reason I like the TV metaphor is it could be further extended. It's really a great addition to the metaphor there. Different notes, they're just the same basic thing, it's music, it's tone. And to the extent that you realize that the substance of talk, image and feel is this doing, this formless field of effervescence, to that extent you become that field. And since it's one world wave, you're linked to the whole spectrum, to the whole symphony for real. So there's four ways that you can get linked to the spiritual source. We all want this. Three of them I call indirect. They're valid. I don't say they're indirect to put them in a lesser position, but they are indirect. And then there's the direct. The three indirect ways, well, you can be linked to the spiritual source through the content of your internal talk. That's been very popular for several thousand years. That's why a lot of the major spiritual traditions have what are called Kratos, which is verbal statements of truth that you accept, that you assent to. So the content of your talk in some way links you to the spiritual truth because you have a belief system. It's no coincidence that over the last several thousand years, maybe five thousand, ten thousand years, the human ego got more and more centered in the verbal mental processing. It's no coincidence that religions shifted into being religion of the word. All fits. And what was the dominant mode before? We had the religions of the word. It was the religion of the image, the image of the gods. You could actually see them. You could actually see the spirits, your dead ancestors. You can actually, not could, you can, even now, if you contact that level of your being. And that was the religion for most of our history, the religion of the seer in the sense of the shamanic vision. That's why they talk about vision quest in those traditions. And then the third indirect way is through, of course, feeling, the sense of the mystery, what the Romans called the numinous, numinosity, not lumen, but numen, N-U-M-E-N, numinosity, the sense of the mystery, felt, not conceived, not visualized, felt. The sense of piety, the sense of devotion, the sense of awe, perhaps fear, perhaps love, bhakti, the rasa, the taste. That is a feeling, a bhava, a bhava, to use the Sanskrit term, a feeling. You can contact the spiritual source through feeling, not through feeling, through a certain kind of feeling that we call religious sentiment. You can contact the spiritual source through a certain kind of talk that we call a belief system. You can contact the spiritual source through vision of the spirit world, which is a certain kind of imaging. Or you can contact the spiritual source as the substance of talk, image, and feeling. And that's what I mean by direct contact with the spiritual source. Then you don't have to go to church anymore because actually you can't go to church anymore at this point. Why? Because you can't leave church. You can't go to church because you can never leave church. Church is everywhere. Church is in the six senses. As an idea, that's sort of ridiculous. But it's not meant to be an idea. It's meant to be something to experience. If you want the religion of ideas, then you can accept a credo. So when you look real carefully, white disappears, red, green, and blue appear. Look a little more carefully, red, green, and blue disappear, and the electromagnetic spectrum appears. When we're not looking carefully, individual self appears, dominates our world. Everything's about I, me, and mine. Look a little more carefully, the I, me, and mine disappears, talk, image, and feel arise in clarity. Look a little more carefully still, talk, image, and feel disappear, and expansion, contraction, and vibration, a vast spectrum, appear. And your individual talk, image, and feel, part of that world wave, directly connected. And to the extent that a person experiences themselves that way, to that extent, they are that source. You've participated. The source isn't a thing, it's a doing. So the extent to which you do it, to that extent, you are it. So that when it comes time for the content of our talk, image, and feel to end at death, we know that we're not the content of our talk, image, and feel only. We know we're something else. And in that sense, we don't notice the difference. That's insight. That's insight. That's an understanding. That allows us to have our cake and eat it too, because we can be our individual selves, manifest an activity of personality, but we can also be our world, and experience a larger identity, a connection with all things. And we can also experience a direct connection with the source of our self and all things. And then we have what we want. Except we don't. We have what we want, as the person that started meditation. But that person that started meditation has gone through a change in a sense of who they are, and what they are. So all of what I've described to you fulfills that individual that started to meditate. But now that individual has a different sense of who they are, so they're not fulfilled. They'll never be fulfilled, ever, ever, ever. Because now they have an endless task, which is to help their larger identity, which is all beings in all conceivable universes. So obviously that task will never be achieved. But because the individual, the individual mind-body process that started meditation, experiences connection with all things and connection with the source, that individual is very fulfilled. But now the goals in practice are different. It's not a personal goal anymore. It's an eternal participation in the beneficent activity of the source, reaching out to its creation. And that's about it.

segments.text: A lot of the procedures that I've been giving you in the guided meditation,
guided meditations so far in the retreat,
I really need to explain to you are not exactly meditation techniques.
They are what I call sensitizing exercises.
And I apologize if it has seemed extremely elaborate and confusing.
Basically, I've mostly given you exercises to explore the interconnection
between the fundamental components of subjective and even to a certain extent
relationships between the subjective components and the objective world.
I made a list of how many different circuits that I'm aware of
that can be teased out in terms of relationships within the subjective triad of talk, image and feel,
and then between the objective world of sight, sound and touch,
and the subjective world of talk, image and feel.
And I got about two dozen.
But that doesn't mean there are two dozen meditation techniques that you're going to have to master.
These, as I say, are just exercises that I give people to sensitize them,
to sort of become aware of relationships,
so that when you do one of the standard techniques, of which there's only a few,
all those strands and connections will have been teased out,
and you'll be able to free-float among talk, image and feel,
or evenly cover, or systematic inventories.
For working with the self, it basically boils down to just those three techniques.
I've also given some of you a way of focusing on the breath,
which is designed to be primarily a concentration exercise,
but also, while it's building concentration, to sensitize you once again to the fundamental elements.
And one can alternate, as I mentioned the first day of the retreat,
there's a complementary interplay between techniques that focus away from the self,
and techniques that focus on the self.
And among the techniques that focus away from the self,
many of them are rather narrow focuses that develop high concentration.
And then you can use that concentration like a laser when you focus on the self,
to get the penetration and the insight.
And you can alternate back and forth between the narrower focus and the broader focus.
However, it's important to realize that even when you do a very narrow focus,
let's say that you were to decide that you wanted to keep things real simple,
just going to focus on the physical sensation of the breath in your abdomen,
or at your nostril, and that's what your path is going to be.
Five years, ten years, fifteen years, twenty years, thirty years,
just keep it simple, that's what you're going to do.
That's enough, that'll do it.
At first it will be a concentration exercise.
Your mind will wander, you bring it back, it wanders, you bring it back.
But if you do it long enough, even those very limited simple focuses
bring elements of insight and purification.
How does that happen?
Well, if you focus on one aspect of experience,
even if your interest is in developing concentration,
you have to be doing some observation of what's going on,
you have to be paying attention to what's going on with the breath.
And the more closely you pay attention,
the more you can start to see how it's constantly changing.
And then, also in order to stay in the moment with it,
you have to be willing to let go, moment by moment,
instant by instant, of the previous sensation there,
in order to be present for the next arising of sensation.
And the sensation begins to melt and yield and dissolve.
Now you're getting insight into impermanence.
Yes, it's impermanence of one little piece of experience,
but it's still impermanence.
And at some point, your perception of impermanence
associated with the sensations of the breath
becomes so great that that impermanence reaches out
and starts to grab the whole body and all the senses,
and you get pulled into a profound insight,
into the insubstantial, oscillatory, and vibratory nature
of all the sense gates,
even though you had a very narrow focus.
So, insight can develop from what is primarily a concentration exercise.
Purification is also there too, although you might not realize it.
Because in order to focus on, let's say, the sensation of the breath,
you're having to let go of a lot of ego patterns.
You can't focus on the sensation of the breath,
and at the same time being involved in talk, image, and feel,
because you're with the touch of the breath.
And if you're really just with the touch of the breath,
you'll start to notice that each time you feel this temptation
to somehow get involved in the content of talk, image, and feel,
and you resist that temptation,
well, you've let go of a little bit of ego grasping there.
You've weakened a little bit of the ego habits.
In fact, one of the reasons that it's so difficult
to focus on a small piece of experience that's neutral, like the breath,
why it feels like you're just going to die, is you are.
A little piece of the ego is going to die.
And it's the time when you would give anything
to indulge some aspect of yourself,
it's at the time when instead of doing that, you stay with the breath,
even though it is literally mortifyingly boring.
It's at that time, whether you realize it or not,
that purification is taking place.
There is a cracking of the ego taking place.
And when it's mortifying, it is mortifying.
It's a petit mort, a little piece of ego death
is taking place at that time.
You might not realize it, as I say,
your primary goal might just be to get a little calm and concentration.
But it's doing what the Yaqui shaman, Don Juan, called
shifting the accumulation point of the universe.
When you just can't stand to focus on that small boring thing anymore
and you still do it, something shifts and the whole universe
is a cracking of a piece of the ego.
So even a narrow focus, if you understand it properly,
brings insight and purification.
But it's helpful to understand it properly.
Personally though, I use a little different strategy
for the insight and purification,
which I would never for a moment claim is any better.
It's just, I like it.
I like to alternate working with individual pieces of experience,
selectively, and then putting those pieces together
and working collectively, and then working once again selectively,
and then working once again collectively.
So you sort of understand the components
and then you understand the relationship with the components.
Why? Because I get bored focusing on something small.
So I find it more interesting to focus on a lot of small things
and then focus on the big picture,
and it just keeps me interested in the meditation process.
And so that's sort of the rationale behind
some of the exercises that I've been giving you.
One of the exercises that I had you do
was pay attention to the sounds around you
and monitor whether a sound produced
a feeling reaction in the body or not,
and then monitor whether a sound produced
an image reaction in the body or not,
and then monitor the effect of the sound on your internal talking,
whether it triggered talk by way of comment about the sound
or whether it turned off talk.
Because self-talk is a kind of internal hearing,
a lot of times external sound will actually turn it off for a minute,
make it silent.
But sometimes it will stimulate it.
If you hear a sound that, you know, let me put it this way,
if you hear a sound and that sound causes a feeling,
very likely there'll be some talk.
So what I was having you do is tease out certain circuits,
the circuit that links sound to talk,
the circuit that links external sound to image,
the circuit that links external sound to a body reaction, a feel.
Then what I had you do is listen to sound
and be aware of what combination of talk, image, and feel
would arise moment by moment in reaction to the sound.
There being exactly eight possibilities.
One of the possibilities being no reaction.
Another possibility being talk, image, and feel arise.
And then you could have just talk, just image, just feel,
or any one of three possible pairs.
The purpose of the exercise, actually quite profound,
because you're exploring how the sense of a perceiving self,
a listening self arises.
How the sense of a listening self arises.
If you do this for some period of time,
and I'm not suggesting you do it,
I'm just saying if one did this,
you would start to gather data.
It's very much like a scientific experiment.
You're not going to get a paradigm shift,
any big ah-ha's or answers, doing it just a few times.
But as you gather a lot of data,
perhaps over a period of weeks, months, maybe years,
you'll start to notice some things.
Insights will start to arise.
Shifts in understanding.
You'll notice that just spontaneously,
every once in a while,
there really is just sound without any reaction.
It just happens.
Not because of this or that,
it's just the probabilities of things.
And as you become sensitive to what that's like,
you'll notice it's quite interesting.
Because when there's just sound,
the sound fills your space and you surround its space,
and you are the sound.
There is just the it and no perceiver.
And that's an extremely...
that expands your boundaries of identity.
Personally, I think an effective strategy
for learning how to do this is not really to try to do it,
but just pay attention to whatever reactions take place
and wait for the law of averages to catch up.
And you'll start to get enough times when there's just sound,
and then it starts to be clear what that is,
and then you can do it as an act of will.
You can decide to just be sound for a while.
Technically, to borrow terminology from another tradition,
from the tradition of yoga,
Raja Yoga, Ashtanga Yoga, Patanjali's Yoga,
the classical yoga of India,
you do understand that the physical yoga is Hatha Yoga.
That's quite something else.
In India, in terms of philosophy,
when you say yoga,
it implies one of the six basic principles
or one of the six classic systems of Indian philosophy,
what are called the Shat Darshana,
the six Darshanas, the six views.
There is the yoga system,
as formulated by Patanjali in the Yoga Sutras,
the Yoga aphorisms.
And there they speak of Sabija Samadhi.
It means samadhi in the sense of merging,
not merely in the sense of concentration,
but in the sense of merging, becoming.
Sabija with a C, that means that
there's no perceiver, but there is the perceived.
And that sounds very mysterious until you start to investigate
your talk, image, and feel reactions to sound.
And then it's not mysterious at all.
You come to realize that every once in a while,
there's just sound.
You don't have to make it happen, it just happens.
It's probabilities.
And when that happens, you are the sound.
There's just the seed, there's just the object,
there's just the sound without a you being there, listening.
Well, you say, well, who hears?
No one. There's just the manifestation of sound.
The sense of someone hearing
always involves some subtle level of talk, image, and feel reaction.
And as you start to see that, you start to get another insight.
You get the insight as to how the sense of a listening self arises.
And when there is a reaction of talk, image, and feel,
there's the sense of I'm over here listening to it over there,
and there's separation.
Is that bad?
No, that's not bad.
It's not bad at all.
Is it better to just be sound and have no separation?
Is that better than the sense of a self arising listening to sound?
No, it's not better.
One is not better than the other.
What's good and bad is as follows.
What's bad is to not know how the sense of self arises
and how the sense of oneness arises.
That's bad.
And what's good is to know that.
Then you're free.
You're free to live in a world of oneness.
You're free to live in a world of separateness.
And you're free from a preference between them.
Because when the self arises separate from the sound,
as long as that self is clear and fluent,
that is to say, you understand why it has arisen.
Because there's talk, image, and feel
happening in reaction to the sound.
And that's natural.
That's as much a part of nature as the cricket's chirping
is part of nature.
That a self should arise in a human being is part of nature.
But for most people, it arises incompletely,
in the sense that they're not aware of the components,
number one, and there is subtle and not so subtle
interference between the components and congealing
and friction and fixation.
The talk, image, and feel don't just flow like a river.
They don't just spread like ripples or blow like the wind.
They're not spirit.
They get frozen, interfered with.
When we say in English,
I became self-conscious, it implies an uncomfortable experience.
That's very strange if you think about it.
Why should it be uncomfortable to be intensely self-conscious?
Suffering equals pain multiplied by resistance.
We must resist the arising of our sense of self.
We must be interfering, pushing and pulling on it,
and therefore it becomes an uncomfortable experience.
So you start to see clearly how the sense of I versus it arises.
You also see what happens when there's not an I versus it,
but there's just it, and I am it.
And that happens with respect to sound,
and it's exactly the same with respect to vision.
In Zen, these are the first koans that are given.
How do you become free when you hear this sound?
That's the classic Sasaki Roshi initial koan.
Or how do you become free when you see the pine tree or see the flower?
What's being asked for?
Well, actually, many levels of experience are being asked for.
One level of experience is you've listened and listened and listened and listened enough
until you start to have that experience of I am the sound.
But I find it, as I say, a little easier if you actually just monitor
the sound and the reactions to the sound, and then that will give you the insights.
And that will also give you the insight of,
the beginning of the insight of how the sense of an individual self arises.
So, okay, that's sound. What about the visual field?
Well, you look here, you look here, you look here.
Each one of those is a new arising of vision.
But what happens when you look at just one thing, like a pine tree?
You're looking just at the pine tree.
Well, your eye goes here, it goes there, it goes there, it goes there.
Your eye traces out the activity of the pine tree,
the structure of the branches and leaves.
And each time it shifts, there is an arising of a piece of the visual field
that constitutes that pine tree.
If there is just the activity of seeing the pine tree,
without any talk, image or feel arising in reaction to each little permutation
of the visual axis, then after 10, 20 seconds of that,
one begins to have the experience of the pine tree fills me,
I embrace the pine tree, I am the pine tree, there is no me.
Of course, substitute pine tree for your lover or your enemy,
and now you're starting to talk about enlightenment,
about really understanding the oneness of things.
Touches on the body, same thing, external physical touches.
How do you become free from hot and cold?
External physical touches, a famous Zen koan,
most of you have heard the answer to it.
I use it at retreats, the monk comes to the Master,
how do you become free from hot and cold?
The Master says, well, why not go to a place where there is no hot or cold?
And the monk says, tell me about that place.
And the Master says, when it's hot, you boil to death.
When it's cold, you freeze to death.
You understand? Boil to death, you're too busy boiling to have talk, image or feel.
You're just heat.
You're too busy freezing to have any reaction, you just have the touch.
No talk, image or feel.
You become hot, you become cold, that's the place where you're free from hot and cold.
Why? Well, as Ananda Maitreya, the grand old man of Sri Lankan Buddhism, put it,
when he was interviewed for the BBC and asked to express in a few words the essence of Buddhism,
he said, I need only four. No self, no problem.
I had the privilege of living with this man in the same Vihara Sri Lankan temple, Sri Lanka.
I was in LA, but I might as well have been in Sri Lanka. It's pretty cool.
So, touch, sight, sound. And what about all of them at once?
Okay, same thing.
How do you become free when you listen to the pine tree, hug it and see it all at once?
Okay, same thing. The external sense is them only.
Sabija Samadhi. There is the shining forth of the object without the sense of self perceiving it.
As I say, you can learn it by trying to do it, or you can learn it by just watching the nature of your reaction
to the external sense impacts without any particular preference,
until you start to see the statistical distribution of reactions and you notice it,
as I say, every once in a while, it just happens.
It happens because there's eight possible reactions, and one of those eight is no talk, no image, no feel.
And if you're watching, watching, watching, over and over and over and over and over again,
you start to notice these things.
One insight is an insight into oneness, how you can be the external world. It's wonderful, it's empowering,
it frees you from fear. Wherever there's fear, there's separateness.
Wherever there's separateness, there's fear. A implies B, B implies A.
That means A and B are exactly the same thing.
So, you can come to oneness by working through fear.
How do you work through fear? By having a complete experience of fear.
Or you can work through fear by experiencing oneness.
How do you experience oneness? I just described it.
If it didn't quite register, that's okay, I'll describe it again and again and again.
I won't get tired of describing it, I promise you that.
So one insight is insight into oneness.
But another insight is insight into how separation arises, and that's important too.
It's deep, very deep.
I can, yes, I can describe it with a metaphor.
The metaphor is very good. It's almost a perfect metaphor.
It just has one flaw. It's not dignified.
And for such a profound and important subject as how the sense of self arises,
I wish I could find a more dignified metaphor,
or at least a more classy or classical sounding metaphor.
But I haven't been able to.
But at least I found what I consider to be a pretty good one.
Many of you have heard it.
I come into your room, you've got your computer on,
and on the screen there's white,
maybe in addition to other colors, whatever,
there are white graphics, a white figure of some sort,
and I tell you, there's no white there.
And you say, come on, you can see it.
And I say, no, there's no white there. You want me to prove it?
I'll give you something that magnifies exactly what is there, changes nothing.
Take this magnifying glass, get close to the screen,
look at the white and tell me exactly what you see
when you look with the magnifying glass close up.
And what will you see? White? What will you see?
Yes, RGB, red, green, and blue pixel dots.
That's what's actually there.
When you look close up with the magnifying glass,
and when you don't look close up with the magnifying glass,
white is there.
So what is the reality of white?
What is the reality of something that appears as soon as you lose contact
with exactly what's there, and disappears as soon as you establish contact
with exactly what's there?
To what extent is that thing there?
It's a very interesting question.
In a sense it's there, I mean, look, it's white.
It's there, but not really.
So it sort of exists and doesn't exist.
I think you can see my metaphor.
Is there a thing called a self inside us?
Well, we all have a sense of self, certainly.
But is there really a limited existence,
a thing called a self inside us, an atma?
It sort of seems that way.
Remember, the Buddha didn't say there wasn't a self.
The Buddha didn't say there wasn't a soul.
The Buddha said there is no atma, or no atta.
He was speaking Sanskrit or a mid-Indian dialect, or Pali,
or something like Pali.
He was not speaking English.
Self is an English word, soul is an English word.
He said there's no atma.
Atma is more or less means self, but not exactly.
It has a different context, it's a different language.
The semantic extent and the connotation of the word in Sanskrit and Pali
and other Indic languages is not exactly the same as English.
So, what implies self as thing?
It's a very reified sense of self, a self-particle.
Buddha was reacting to that perception of self.
And we have that perception, undeniably.
We have the perception that there's a thing inside us called a self.
But is there?
Well, it's quite analogous to the white on the computer screen.
If you don't look carefully, it's there.
But if you take the magnifying glass of mindfulness
and investigate what's actually there,
what's actually there is talk, image, and feel,
either in its clear form or its subtle subliminal forms.
That's what's actually there.
And the interesting thing is, as soon as you take the magnifying glass of mindfulness
to the perception of I am a thing,
the I am-ness goes away, just like the white does,
and you're left with talk, image, and feel.
So, how does the sense of self arise?
It arises when talk, image, and feel arise, and you lose contact with them.
And when talk, image, and feel arise and you have a complete experience of them,
you're able to not lose contact with them,
then the sense of self, this thing, does not arise.
Then what does arise?
Moksha, a sense of freedom,
as opposed to a sense of limited identity.
So that's why it's perfectly okay that there be a reaction of talk, image, and feel
to sight, sound, and touch,
as long as you're able to keep track of it and don't interfere with it.
Then you'll have a kind of self, but it's a clear and fluent self.
Therefore we call it a transparent and insubstantial self,
or self as activity, as opposed to self as thing.
So that's a big insight.
So by tracking, like I say, I know that some of the exercises I gave you are pretty frustrating.
There is a reason behind it.
By tracking these kinds of relationships, we can get insights fairly readily.
How can we become one with our world?
And how does the sense of separateness arise specifically?
What's involved? What are the steps? What are the components? What are the relationships?
So in one experience of samadhi, there is just sight, sound, touch as an object,
and no talk, image, and feel at all.
In another aspect of samadhi, talk, image, and feel may arise by way of reaction,
but it's so clear and fluent that it is diaphanous, it is transparent.
So once again, there is just sight, sound, and touch. I am the world.
But there is a deeper samadhi than that.
There is nirbija samadhi, samadhi without a seed.
What does that mean?
Well, I've talked about sight, sound, and touch arising as an object,
but if you have a complete experience of sight, sound, or touch,
you're too busy experiencing it to congeal it into a thing.
So then what happens is, not only does the sense of self arise as a flow of nothingness,
but the thing that you're concentrating on, the sound, arises as a flow of nothingness.
And there is what is called formless samadhi.
You're merged, but you're so completely merged that there's no knowing.
That's why it's called asamprajñāta samadhi.
It's another term for it. I'm using yogic terms here, but it's the same as Buddhism, let's be honest.
When the Zen Master was talking about going to a place where there is no hot and cold,
it wasn't just that there is no self experiencing hot and cold,
but it also implied that the experience of hot and cold was so complete
that hot and cold as an object disappeared.
Now that may seem rather bleak, but actually it's very rich,
because the self and the object don't disappear into bleakness, they disappear into completeness.
The experience is so rich that it doesn't exist anymore.
Not that it's so deprived that it doesn't exist anymore.
So because the path to the emptiness is by having more and more and more complete experiences,
the emptiness is perceived as extremely rich, in fact as the ultimately rich.
I know it's a paradox, it doesn't really make a lot of sense when you try to put it into words,
but all the mystics all around the world in all the ages agree on this,
and a lot of them never communicated with each other, they just discovered it independently.
Sort of like the Pythagorean theorem.
The Greeks discovered it on their own, the Chinese discovered it on their own,
people in India discovered it on their own, but it's the same theorem,
because it's intrinsic in the nature of mathematical reality.
You know the Pythagorean theorem? Can you quote it? Sure you can.
Don't you remember the Wizard of Oz when the scarecrow gets his brains?
Remember? And he's got his brains, and the way he proves it is,
the square on the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares on the other two sides?
That's the Pythagorean theorem.
Except Ray Bolger flubbed his lines. He didn't say it quite right,
and every mathematician just cringes when they hear the Wizard of Oz.
I forgot, but I remember I listened carefully, because after I read that,
I listened carefully, and it's true, the lines are flubbed.
It's not actually the Pythagorean theorem.
It's just that's so fundamental to mathematics.
I mean, it's like you just cringe if you're a mathematician, if it's not done right.
Well, just like the Pythagorean theorem is a universal reality,
this rich bleakness of the source is independently discovered in the different traditions,
which gives us a strong indication that there's something there.
It's not something true, because it's not limited to one tradition.
I said that the TV metaphor was a pretty good one,
because not only does it give an analog to how a property emerges,
it's what's called an emergent property in consciousness science.
The white is an emergent property.
It magically emerges from red, green, and blue.
It's not red, it's not green, it's not blue, and it's not a compromise.
It's not a mixture of red, green, and blue. It's a completely different critter.
The sense of I am a limited identity, I am a thing,
it's not talk, it's not image, it's not feel, and it's not some compromise between those.
It's a completely different thing that somehow emerges from those when you lose track of them.
And it fails to emerge when you stay with just what is.
The reason I like the TV metaphor is it could be further extended.
So, okay, so now you know that the sense of limited identity
comes about when you lose track of the components of subjective experience.
But then, there's still those components, what are they?
So now we know, okay, so the limited identity is sort of real and sort of not real,
and that gives us quite a different paradigm on ourselves.
And we also know that we can become our external world,
which is pretty earth-shaking, literally.
But so what is, so now we see there's red, green, and blue, there's no more white,
but what's red, green, and blue? What are they?
This is where it gets interesting.
But what is red? What is green? What is blue in the larger picture of things?
Different frequencies, or put alternatively, different wavelengths of something called what?
Electromagnetic energy.
Radiant energy.
Energy that is carried by nothing.
Fluctuations of the void.
We talk about things like radio waves, that's, a radio wave is one kind of,
one band of wavelengths or frequencies of electromagnetic energy.
Well, you know what a water wave is, you can see the energy carried by a water wave,
it's mechanical energy, not radiant energy, it's mechanical energy.
And you can see that those water waves must carry energy
because they can wear down the rocky shore with that energy.
The water is the medium, the physical medium that carries the energy,
so what's the physical medium that carries electromagnetic energy?
What's between us and the star through which the wave of light comes?
What's the medium?
There ain't any. There ain't any.
There's just empty space.
There's just empty space, so somehow empty space vibrates in a way that we can't really conceive of,
and energy is transmitted.
So red, green, and blue are merely tiny frequencies on a broad spectrum of energy that runs, what,
24 orders of magnitude in terms of frequency? I don't know, something absolutely awesome.
Absolutely awesome.
A piano runs, what, eight octaves?
How many octaves on a piano?
An organ's five octaves?
So octaves are doublings.
Do you have any idea how many octaves there are on the electromagnetic spectrum?
Well, if you start with the very, very slow biological rhythms, and then you go to cosmic rays,
I think that the cosmic rays are approximately 10 to the 24th faster than the biological rhythms.
